text: hi everyone thoughts than he prayers
tano here the internet's busiest music
nerd
and it is time for a review of the new
liturgy album
origin of the alimonies this is a new
album slash
opera from one of the most
ground-breaking names
in modern metal music hunter hunt
hendricks's
liturgy hunter is a guitarist singer
composer and theologian who has been
recording music for years
specifically as the main brain of this
ever-evolving avant metal project
which has undergone quite a
metamorphosis over the years
under the guise of transcendental black
metal especially lately with hunter
working more
classically leaning instrumentation into
her pieces
pushing liturgy's legendary sonic peaks
of intensity even higher
we caught notes of that albeit rough
ones on the arc work a few years back
then on liturgy's hack record that
dropped last year as well as
on the antigone single this year and in
an interview i had with hunter just a
few months back now
she told me she was working on a literal
liturgy opera
and frankly i didn't expect it to come
out so soon
and be so approachable for most popular
music listeners i think opera tends to
be
a pretty foreign thing which could be
due to a number of factors
lack of overall exposure the insularity
of the culture
but remember that opera has already
proven itself to have a life
outside of your madame butterflies and
your carmens
you know rock operas are in fact a thing
and while hunter rightfully frames
origin of the alimonies as an opera
more in the traditional sense if you're
open to the idea of
using rock and metal instrumentation to
make
grand and theatrical and narrative
statements
then there's really no reason to go into
this new liturgy project
skeptically especially since it has such
a concise run time and works in three
very well-defined acts
there's the first track serving as the
overture of the piece
following that with act one narratively
is olawan's birth and
loneliness then in act 2 we see another
character or alimony in this opera
sem whose fall and lament is depicted at
this point
following this we have a 14 minute
interlude on the project which is
actually one of the most
thunderous and consequential moments on
the entire lp
an expansion and a reworking of an organ
piece from oliver messiah
which also very much plays into the
religious and classical aspects of the
music and storytelling here then the
third act of this opera is held together
by the closer the armistice which by
definition is an
agreement made by opposing parties to
stop
fighting stop warring which narratively
makes sense because the lyrics of this
portion
on the album detail the two other
additional alimonies which are a part of
hunter's theological philosophy being
birthed by the two that have been
introduced up until this point
sem and olalon so one thing about this
opera that should already be obvious at
this point but i will mention explicitly
is that hunter is
really confronting listeners with the
theological end
of liturgy's conceptual makeup here this
record
isn't just a batch of mathy fluid
dynamic brain melting black metal
bangers
to put it simply it's a musical story of
the metaphysical basics of all things
or alimonies as hunter calls them which
probably sounds really convoluted or
even culty but
please let me remind you that again this
is a personal philosophy this is not an
invitation to join a commune or anything
and
there is sound philosophical depth to
the liturgical aspects
of liturgy the charts and the complex
terminology and the
concepts are not just window dressing
this in a way
is an attempt by hunter to explain
the functions and the existence and the
strife in our world
just as any other religious institution
might
which is another reason why hunter's
ambitions here are not so far-fetched
so i'm sorry if this seems like too much
i mean the music here in my opinion is a
lot easier to explain but i do think you
would be doing yourself a disservice if
you were to go into this album without
appreciating at least a little bit
the narrative and the story going on
here i think it would be a lot like
watching a great movie and only
appreciating it for its
cinematography from end to end and
walking away from it
having not recalled any of the storyline
whatsoever not to get too corny about it
or anything
but i actually see the origin of the
alimonies here as a prequel of sorts
if we see everything liturgy's been
doing as a succession
then this record is definitely going
back to the beginning giving us the
building blocks that all of the records
we've been hearing rest upon
having said all that the musical
functions of the seven
movements within this opera are pretty
straightforward
epic exciting envelope pushing but still
straightforward
the opera kicks off with the separation
of hawk from heil
where some violin flute and trumpet
curiously feel out these eerie
foreboding melodies
which slowly develop over the course of
several minutes
into a layered drone complete with these
glitchy
skips and edits that were pretty
prominently featured on the last liturgy
record
more instrumentation and dissonance
comes into the fold as the piece
progresses
then the final minute is quite harrowing
it explodes into a
mountain of classical and metal
instrumentation it's an experimental
metal
opera just thundering away
overpowering it's a grand entrance and
contrasts nicely with the following
hololens birth
which is not just an alimony of sorts
but a character in this
opera instrumentally it sounds like an
inception point for sure
lots of dark brooding organ calling out
against
dissonant layers of strings flute and
trumpet for one minute and 40 seconds or
so
it's a lot of tension building and
transitions smoothly into the following
lonely olalon
which quickly gains composure with some
heart-wrenching and righteous chord
progressions
it's at this point where the musical
makeup of the opera resembles that
of liturgy's earlier works which i think
makes sense since narratively we're
going back to the past to explain the
origin of something plus hunter
creatively balances these more familiar
bits out with
orchestral sections that add a lot of
drama to the piece once again it feels
like hunter is trying to push liturgy's
dynamic limitations with
more instrumentation and greater builds
and for the most part i think it's
working
especially with the fantastic crescendo
of horns and strings
ascending over the rhythm guitars in the
second leg
everything in the mix just melts into
this powerful beam of sound that is
just cinematic the next two movements in
the opera the fall of sem and sem's
lament
follow a similar pattern of abstraction
and tension building
and then cathartic release the first of
the two pieces
starts off patiently and subtly enough
but eventually builds into this intense
wall of free-form jazz inspired rock
instrumentation
sounds a little like king crimson or
even
soft machine or something in between for
the finale of the track we have every
instrument in the mix just
laying into a wall of sound that is so
overpowering
it rivals anything that swans have been
doing on their past
several records then sems lament is
maybe the weirdest but most effective
combination
of genres that i've heard this year the
intro is certainly a lot to take in
between the digitally manipulated
background vocals
trap rhythms and very dry midi
instrumentation
and on the surface while this portion of
the track does come off a little awkward
i think there is some
intent there especially considering how
organic and fluid the
orchestral bits sound in contrast maybe
this piece could be taken as a statement
also
as a juxtaposition of organic and
synthetic sounds maybe modern and
classic i'm sure there are a host of
contrasts
one could draw plus compositionally from
this point there are so many
radical changes going on in the piece
it's hard to
keep up with all of them it's very
thrilling and packed into a
super tight several minutes that include
these minimalistic propulsive flute
sections as well as these down tuned
riffs that
come off doom inspired following this
the rework the apparition of the eternal
church interlude i alluded to earlier
comes through
which feels like a journey within the
album itself and personally while i do
love the various chord changes across
the track
along with how hunter works in these
liturgy-esque
guitar passages there's a lot of
contrast across the piece
i'm not crazy about how these discordant
pianos keep up this quarter note pacing
in the background it just seems like a
really
weird and passive way of keeping with
the rhythm of the piece
it's not until the strings come into
play that i feel like it all comes
together the second half is generally
gratifying as a result
i just think up until that point it runs
a little tedious
then the armistice is a grand moment of
finality for the entire record
where as i said earlier narratively we
have the other two alimonies being
birthed from the ones that we were
introduced to
in the track list this is represented
with
every piece of instrumentation in
hunter's arsenal just
piling on in as panoramic a display as
as one could
create by the time it's over it
certainly feels like something has
begun something has been birthed so i'll
say overall i loved this piece i think
it is a respectable addition to the
liturgy canon
were there some moments that i thought
were a little rough yes
here and there and also do i wish there
was more to it maybe some movements that
more specifically address the other two
alimonies that are introduced toward the
finish of the opera
but either way hunter's liturgy here
continues an
incredible streak of records and
projects deepens the lore in the process
and i think gives anybody who's really
paying attention
quite a bit of insight into all of the
theology that makes up liturgy's
conceptual
dna i'm feeling a light too decent eight
on this one
